title: “Apocalypso”: Visions of Cosmopolitanism in Michelle Cliff's Fiction

reference.unstructured: I am thinking here, most notably, of Said'sOrientalism(1979) andCulture and Imperialism(1994).

Cf. Bhabha's notion of hybridity inThe Location of Cultureand “Cosmopolitanisms.” See alsoAshcroft,Griffins, andTiffin, as well as Glissant's rhizomatic model of interperipheral networks inPoetique de la Relation(1990) andTraite du Tout-Monde(1997).
Cf.Hallemeier,J. M. Coetzee and the Limits of Cosmopolitanism.

In his manifestoQu'est-ce que la litterature(1948), Jean-Paul Sartre makes a distinction between poetry, concerned with the materiality of language, and prose, which, according to him, uses language instrumentally as a vehicle of communication. Referring to the discursive language of prose, Sartre displaces the traditional opposition between political act and literary word in noting that to speak is to act. In asserting that by speaking one reveals the situation in which one is found, he defines the prosewriter as someone “who has chosen a certain method of secondary action which we may call action by disclosure…. The ‘committed’ (engage) writer knows that words are action. He knows that to reveal is to change and one can reveal only by planning to change. He has given up the impossible dream of giving an impartial picture of Society and the human condition” (3). Sartre espouses the aesthetic mode of realism, which he sees as the appropriate medium for disclosing the world with the intention of changing it. Sartre's controversial stance laid the groundwork in the decades that followed for attempts to reconfigure the relationship between literature and politics, and in the process brought about intense rethinking of the power and status of literature, and art more broadly, in society. His notion of engagement also has had a prominent presence in discussions concerning the status of literature, the novel in particular, and the role of the writer in pre-independence colonies and later in emergent postcolonial literatures. For a comprehensive overview of the influence of this debate in postcolonial literature and theory see Taoua.
Cf.Hallemeier,J.M. Coetzee and the Limits of Cosmopolitanism.
